perturbation.original_text: 5.2 Contractor's Right to Terminate Agreement for any Reason. The Contractor may terminate this Agreement and his or her engagement for any reason at any time upon providing 30 days advance notice in writing to Emerald. Termination will be effective, at Emeralds' election, on a date which is no earlier than the date such notice is received and no later than the date which is 30 days following that date.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2 Contractor's Right to Terminate Agreement for any Reason. The Contractor may terminate this Agreement and his or her engagement for any reason at any time upon providing 5 days advance notice in writing to Emerald. Termination will be effective immediately upon Emerald's receipt of such notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires 30 days' notice for the Contractor to terminate the agreement. The modified text reduces this to 5 days and makes the termination effective immediately upon receipt, potentially conflicting with employment standards that might require longer notice periods, depending on how a court interprets the independent contractor relationship. This immediate termination could also be seen as unconscionable or a breach of good faith.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of British Columbia Employment Standards Act regarding reasonable notice, depending on court interpretation of contractor's de facto employment status.

perturbation.original_text: 5.4 Emeralds' Right to Terminate this Agreement without Cause. The Company may terminate this Agreement and the engagement of the Contractor without Cause at any time on 30 days prior written notice. The date of termination will be the date specified in the written notice and must be a date, which is not earlier than the required notice period.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.4 Emeralds' Right to Terminate this Agreement without Cause. The Company may terminate this Agreement and the engagement of the Contractor without Cause at any time on 1 week prior written notice. The date of termination will be the date specified in the written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides 30 days' notice for termination without cause. The modified text reduces this to 1 week. Depending on the specific circumstances and interpretation of the contractor's role, this shorter notice period could be deemed unreasonable and violate implied contractual obligations or relevant employment standards if the contractor is considered a de facto employee.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of implied contractual terms or British Columbia Employment Standards Act regarding reasonable notice, contingent on the court's interpretation of the relationship.

perturbation.original_text: 5.5 Consequences of Termination of Agreement. All obligations of the Company to the Contractor hereunder shall immediately terminate and cease as of the date of the termination of the Contractor's engagement. The Company shall only be obliged to pay the Fees agreed to but not yet paid as of the date of termination, with such payment to be made within 30 days of the date of termination.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.5 Consequences of Termination of Agreement. All obligations of the Company to the Contractor hereunder shall immediately terminate and cease as of the date of the termination of the Contractor's engagement. The Company shall only be obliged to pay the Fees agreed to but not yet paid as of the date of termination, with such payment to be made within 90 days of the date of termination.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies payment of outstanding fees within 30 days of termination. The modified text extends this to 90 days. This delay could violate prompt payment laws, or laws requiring timely payment of wages upon termination, if the contractor is deemed to be an employee in substance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of prompt payment laws or wage laws requiring timely payment upon termination in British Columbia.
